Bitcoin ETFs approved: deepening trust and transparency in crypto

On January 10, the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) undertook the landmark step of approving 11 spot Bitcoin exchange traded funds (ETFs). The SEC‚Äôs green light paves the way for these ETFs to trade on US securities exchanges and comes after a decade-long journey to obtain approval for spot Bitcoin ETFs - a journey that involved intense legal battles and debates about the sou

On January 10, the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) undertook the landmark step of approving 11 spot Bitcoin exchange traded funds (ETFs). The SEC‚Äôs green light paves the way for these ETFs to trade on US securities exchanges and comes after a decade-long journey to obtain approval for spot Bitcoin ETFs - a journey that involved intense legal battles and debates about the soundness of Bitcoin-linked investment products. 

13:41 • 6 days ago

Matterium

CAN THE BLOCKCHAIN SAVE THE YOUNG (from themselves)?

The Real Politics of the Blockchain One of the arguments for why Octopuses have not managed to make the jump to high technology in the past few million years is that, despite being spookily intelligent, their young are free floating little sea creatures rather than being raised by parents. No way to build culture. EVERY GENERATION STARTS FROM ZERO. Humans can‚Äôt start from zero‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääwe need to
The Real Politics of the Blockchain

One of the arguments for why Octopuses have not managed to make the jump to high technology in the past few million years is that, despite being spookily intelligent, their young are free floating little sea creatures rather than being raised by parents. No way to build culture. EVERY GENERATION STARTS FROM ZERO.

Humans can‚Äôt start from zero‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääwe need to learn from previous generations.

Today‚Äôs younger generations are as adrift on the internet, on the infinite seas of the information environment, as baby octopuses are in the vast depths of the open ocean. The only things which are stable reference points are archaic (religion) or capitalised (product-based identities). Equally abyssal.

But Humans can‚Äôt start from zero‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääwe need to learn from previous generations. Some say cave paintings were used to teach younger people how to hunt! We have been at this a while.

https://smarthistory.org/bhimbetka-cave-paintings-2/

So I‚Äôm thinking again about how to handle the political disenfranchisement of young people through the blockchain, building on something I wrote a while back. The hopes and dreams of a better world where people have individual agency and great collective power are deep-rooted in blockchain culture. Can we deliver that dream?

I believe we can but it needs some careful cultural thinking about how young people got so screwed over by the economy and socially atomized, and what might be needed to fix it. It‚Äôs all about ‚Äúfrontier‚Äù and getting away from incumbents to places where it‚Äôs genuinely possible to create something.

Also humans live a really, really long time which means you can have me‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääa Gen X ‚Äú90s kid‚Äù‚Ää‚Äî‚Äätell you what I think about the situation. In contrast Octopuses only live about five years so their elders are pre-school. But in the 1990s we had almost exactly the same obsessions that the current generation has and my hope is that we can help you find a way fowards.

Does any of this look familiar? Hell we‚Äôre even fighting the same companies.

Burning Man 1996: Helco - Trippingly

Can we deliver the dream?

I was part of an internet community in the early 1990s. People all over the world. Our symbol? A simple ‚Äú@‚Äú because nobody else had a cultural identity as an email user.

Just think about that for a second. You‚Äôre driving around in some suburb looking for your friend‚Äôs house, that you only know from the internet, and you pass a mailbox with an ‚Äú@‚Äú symbol printed on a piece of paper and taped to the outside of the mailbox. ‚ÄúInternet People Here‚Äù. It‚Äôs like seeing the Bitcoin logo on a shop, or the Ethereum logo on a conference.

You know that in this place you‚Äôre part of The Network.

Go back to the age of rail and there were Hobo Code symbols. The ‚Äú@‚Äú symbol was our technomad code. ‚ÄúInternet People Here‚Äù.

That‚Äôs 30 years ago. It‚Äôs as distant from 2023 as the 1960s were for us in the 1990s. It‚Äôs an entire world away.

Fashion used to play the same role. Subcultural branding and tagging and identity all woven together. You‚Äôve seen these guys? London in the 1980s had one of the most extreme fashion subcultures ever seen. That version of punk was expensive in money and opportunity costs. Social proof!

The people that paid that cost were in it together against the world‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääout-in group.

Of course, with those people it was:

Today, by and large, young people are not responding like this; it is notable that in the 21st century the thriving ferment of street subcultures has largely died out except as nostalgia trends (although, even then, no one has brought back psychobilly‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääno one should bring back psychobilly).

So now everybody‚Äôs on the internet. Young people who skipped college are sitting around at home trading crypto in their teens, and then moving to Singapore for tax reasons in their 20s (or whatever). In an infinite sea of faces, who are your people? Who do you invest in knowing? And I do mean ‚Äúinvest in knowing‚Äù‚Ää‚Äî‚Äärelationship building takes time, and young people invest in it very, very, hard.

Who do you invest in knowing?

Today, while young people still deal with this through aesthetics, these are wider ranging and more diffuse than just clothing, and they do it through social media. Let‚Äôs talk social media‚Äôs ‚Äúaesthetic‚Äù obsession. From Cottagecore to Dark Academia, what does social media‚Äôs obsession with creating aesthetics say about us? And why is it such a problem? The aesthetic subcultures folks follow ‚Äúalpha‚Äù (information) flows, and you need money to buy in. You become a ‚ÄúVSCO girl‚Äù or go ‚ÄúCottagecore‚Äù and it costs you a few dozen hours of analysis and a few thousand dollars of purchases. Now you look like Those Other People. Outside of college campuses etc. the Cottagecore Community doesn‚Äôt really meet in reality. This is all online. It‚Äôs much the same economic cost as buying into a mid-price NFT project. It‚Äôs almost like we‚Äôre all trying to anchor in the enormous full emptiness of the internet.

You can see the same thing in the photography ‚Äúcommunity‚Äù‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääall the Fuji buyers making ‚Äúfilm like‚Äù into a thing, while the Nikon buyers are showing off their P1000 shots of birds feeding their babies 4.5km away with the superzoom goodness. It‚Äôs markets being used as community mediums. Buy this product to find your people.

Other people anchor through economics. I think that the heavy slant of the blockchain space towards libertarianism, autism, Asperger‚Äôs, Nerd Culture, and the general social blunting that comes with working with machines (I could hardly talk when I was a computer graphics engineer) is partly responsible for this. Crypto-socio-economics‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääbinding people together with economically shared incentives through things like NFTs or DAOs is a nerd response to living in an atomized society.‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääwith people for whom aesthetics don‚Äôt appeal, economics may do the job of bringing people together.

Other people anchor through economics

So I think what‚Äôs happening in the NFT space, and to a limited degree in stuff like L2 chains or crappy little L1s, is a similar kind of social anchoring. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve got $20,000 of Dogecoin? Well we‚Äôre 100% on the same team. Go Doge!‚Äù Because otherwise people just drift away online. There‚Äôs no cost to leaving the community so people do, often silently.

The only way we know how to answer the question of ‚Äúwho are you?‚Äù Is socially.

Family names. ‚ÄúJohn of Sudbury‚Äù. ‚ÄúJoe Baker‚Äù. Given names. I travelled all over America in the 1990s on ‚Äú@‚Äú. The story of ‚Äúwho am I?‚Äù was tightly coupled to the social technology of the day: email lists. I don‚Äôt think nearly enough work has been done on the ‚Äúeconomic sociology‚Äù of crypto projects, particularly DAOs and NFT communities. Now that I‚Äôm seeing this head-on, it all makes so much more sense. A single framework with aesthetic and ‚Äú-core‚Äù cultures, NFTs and DAOs together. This also neatly explains the early adopter communities on Twitter, Instagram and, earlier than that, Flickr (really the first social network for people that made images rather than writing as a way of expressing their identity)‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääinfluencers as social leaders: reference point organisers. In ancient times this was one of the functions of soap operas: people who worked in the same office but lived in different communities could gossip about people they both ‚Äúknew‚Äù outside of the workplace, those being the cast of Friends etc‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäYes, I know this sounds incredibly dumb. But 30 years ago (!) there were academic publications as people discovered this phenomena!

https://www.dhi.ac.uk/san/waysofbeing/data/communication-zangana-baym-1993.pdf Who‚Äôs writing the equivalent paper today about NFTs?

I don‚Äôt think nearly enough work has been done on the ‚Äúeconomic sociology‚Äù of crypto projects

So the idea that what we have is economic responses to social atomization is not a new one but I‚Äôm seeing it in a new way because I‚Äôve got it from two sides right now: ‚Äúaesthetic‚Äù culture from YouTube etc. and NFT/DAO from crypto.

This is almost gendered, women and men. Almost.

As we have transformed our physical and social environment further and further from the environment that we evolved in, it becomes harder and harder for us to find the true happiness which is harmony between our own nature and nature itself. We love dogs and BBQs beside water. No form of happiness is more universal than a few families and friends gathering to grill food on a beach or by a lake. That‚Äôs where we evolved. That‚Äôs our native environment at its best.

Food, fire and friends beside water.

Friends, dogs, and faint wood smoke

Ape Utopia.

That‚Äôs what people are seeking in these internet cultures, but are they finding it?

Once, in the ‚Äô90s, when the internet was young, we did this with mailing lists and newsgroups, we had little social communities where like-minded people found each other and generated whole new friendship groups that didn‚Äôt rely on geography or finding the right pub. There‚Äôs even an archived list of all the ‚Äúcyberpunk‚Äù email lists from the 1990s. Isn‚Äôt that amazing? It was all DIY and profoundly uncommercial. but this was basically commodified and destroyed by social media that first co-opted it, then corrupted it by filtering the messages and monetising the interactions, so the groups no longer felt like ‚Äúhome‚Äù.

This was commodified and destroyed by social media

You can see why an entire generation of innovators latched on to crypto because it seemed like it could, in theory, reinvent that uncommercial sense of online community by owning the commercial aspects collectively, and then offer social solidarity at the ‚Äútribal‚Äù and potentially even the ‚Äúmunicipal‚Äù level through larger projects like Ethereum.

Ethereum Nation.

But it‚Äôs all stretched. We can‚Äôt actually live inside of the metaverse. The people who own the same NFTs as you do might be too far away and too alien to babysit your kids. The core biological reality of our lives is only very slightly improved by online community. Life still happens in the real world and this is what‚Äôs producing the crazy addictive (often life damaging) effects: it doesn‚Äôt matter how much you drink wine if what you need is coffee. The strongest online communities are still only reflections and shadows of ‚Äúfood, fire and friends beside water.‚Äù Social media does not give people what they actually need. That‚Äôs why we keep scrolling.

We can‚Äôt actually live inside of the metaverse

People are growing up untethered: fashion doesn‚Äôt indicate identity when you can drop $200 at Shein and walk out with an entirely new wardrobe. There‚Äôs no social cost to weird hair. There‚Äôs no geographic binding after high school really. The idea that what we have is a set of broad pathologies based on the conditions of internet atomization resulting in community inclusion being mediated by products, in other words you have to buy your friends, is fucking brutal. I‚Äôve heard it before, but only understood it for myself now; it is a desperate position for a social monkey to find itself in.

Community inclusion being mediated by products is fucking brutal

This is not the utopia you are seeking‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit‚Äôs ‚Äúpay to play tribalism‚Äù. This is unfortunate. You can see the perfect opportunity for people being exploited: you want to join a tribe and get to know people. You want to make money. The two impulses are joined in the DAO structure: a community you buy into. It‚Äôs a little bit like having a cult with elected leadership, or a multi-level marketing scheme which is owned by the members. The social dynamics are very similar to both cults and MLMs. The social dynamics fuse capitalism and society in a new and probably kinda dangerous way.

It‚Äôs ‚Äúpay to play tribalism‚Äù

Clearly there‚Äôs a social binding force‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääbut with that come problems. The combination of social solidarity and commerce is unsafe. We cannot make an atomized population powerful with either shallow social organisation or technology. To save the world‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääand here I‚Äôm thinking climate change‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääwe need the most profound de-atomization imaginable (or maybe geoengineering).

We‚Äôre in a maze.

We‚Äôre building technologies without the end goal in sight. What people want at a shallow advertising-driven level and what people need at a ‚Äúmy life is whole and makes sense to me‚Äù level are way different. Instagram does not substitute for a better relationship with your sister. And this is the fundamental challenge of the ‚Äúreal world assets‚Äù phase of Ethereum. OK, now we can handle real estate on the blockchain in tokenized form. We really can: http://mattereum.com/land is a real deal and there‚Äôs way more coming.

Instagram does not substitute for a better relationship with your sister

But can we solve the social problems too? We‚Äôre already seeing the broad outlines of this attempt: Network States are ‚Äúcrypto communities do real estate‚Äù with kinda strange Silicon Valley logic applied.

Once you tease out the projects that are the Silicon Valley equivalent of a Sovereign Citizen play (i.e. opting out of existing nation state structures to avoid tax and law, while still physically living in the state) what they are is electronic communities organised around money rather than community: the people grew up atomized: never felt community. We get regular pings from people with ambitions of doing community land projects and building physical settlements with crypto finance as an integral part of the start up plan, often with community governance done using DAOs or other crypto voting methods.

People are reaching.

This is really the key.

If we‚Äôre going to ship large-scale community-oriented real estate development projects that actually deliver ‚Äúfood, fire and friends beside water‚Äù at scale we‚Äôre going to need to figure out the sociological issues which have made modern community so hard. Winding up a Network State that failed is going to be much harder than winding up a company or shuttering a community.

People think they want tokenized real estate. They need community. They won‚Äôt be happy with tokenized real estate unless it delivers community.

That is part of why there is so much interest in DAOs and Network States. People want to be reconnected to each other. That‚Äôs the fundamental human drive at the heart of all of this. Yes, professional real estate clients want faster transactions and so on. Yes, Mattereum can deliver that. But their clients want community. The enormous cultural push towards de-atomizing society and returning to interconnected forms is unstoppable: it is human nature returning to being human after centuries of industrial oppression.

Post-industrial society is like post-war society: an attempt to return to peace.

Professional real estate clients want faster transactions but their clients want community

As we move down the pathway towards tokenized community real estate projects, whether they be Network States or start-up villages or just plain old electronic communes, we‚Äôre going to wind up having to try and bring wisdom about community, not just the Mattereum legals.

It‚Äôs not like I haven‚Äôt lived in communities and studied them in detail for more than 30 years.

I do have grounded opinions about how to do this, and I think if we invested in researchers and worked closely with clients we could actually deliver functional community templates. And that is, after all, probably the highest good that Mattereum can deliver to retail customers: better arrangements for buying their houses and managing shared assets with their neighbours.

The highest good that Mattereum can deliver: better arrangements for buying houses and managing shared assets

Professional finance needs precision and efficiency. But homeowners need warm relations. Bad governance and bad finance produce stone cold grinding poverty: Homeowners Associations and sharecropping. If we actually go into this tokenized real estate thing with a clear sense of the end goals in mind it might be a lot easier than we think: nobody‚Äôs tried with lawyers. ‚ÄúGood fences make good neighbours‚Äù, and a contract is nothing but a fence of written words. The legal structures are all there: there‚Äôs no reason for Homeowners Associations to be terrible.

There‚Äôs no reason shared ownership has to be predatory. Societies do not have to be the way they are; we can change them.

So‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääwhat does this all mean? Well, my parents‚Äô generation were part of the post-war economic boom. The economy was buoyant and everyone, whatever their income was, floated up on the tide. Until, basically, the 1980s; Thatcher, Reagan and neo-liberal economics, which, as a matter of policy, was ‚Äúevery person for themselves‚Äù‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääthere‚Äôs no such thing as society. Those who had money were able to leverage more at the expense of those with less, because money translates to power, allowing them to become obscenely rich while everyone else‚Äôs income stagnated. We weren‚Äôt going to do better than our parents, the first generation in a century to say that.

see also https://wtfhappenedin1971.com/

For my parents, stability and community was home, family, the workplace. Young people today are priced out of owning a house, or even stably renting one, there‚Äôs no expectation of long-term jobs or even a single career through your working life, let alone staying in the same place. But they still want ‚Äúfood, fire and friends beside water‚Äù (and also cats) and where they are looking for it is online, but the neo-liberals got there first and have commodified, monetized and corrupted the will for online community, so they end up basically with ‚Äúpay-to-play‚Äù friends. Is it any wonder people are starting to have romantic relationships with AI Chatbots? The blockchain offers a way round that, a means to create a self-generated trusted community, to build structures that are egalitarian, supportive and nurturing through DAOs and similar. To do this needs more than good will, it needs law, it needs appropriate fences to keep out the thieves, scammers and profiteers. The current global operating system is broken, its head has been severed and it is running on reflexes, not quite aware it is dead yet. Politicians pull the levers and wonder why they no longer work, resorting to ‚Äúdead cat‚Äù distractions to hide the fact they have no functioning policies.

Nettles need to be grasped and the rough beast slouching towards Bethlehem needs to take form.

There are ways forward. We need to build them.

Next, I will take a look at possible ways to do this‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääwatch this space!

CAN THE BLOCKCHAIN SAVE THE YOUNG (from themselves)? was originally published in Mattereum - Humanizing the Singularity on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

11:22 • 6 days ago

Ocean Protocol

‚ÄòRoad to Safety: Traffic Accident Analysis‚Äô Data Challenge Launch

Data vs. Disaster - Can you crack the code to safer roads and traffic accidents in Spain‚Äôs region of Catalunya? 2024 marks the 3rd year of the Ocean Protocol Data Challenge Program initiative. ‚ÄòRoad to Safety: Traffic Accident Analysis‚Äô is the first data challenge in 2024. The challenge launches today Jan 11, 2024, with a deadline to participate ending Jan 30, 2024, 23:59:59 UTC. Access to the ch

Data vs. Disaster - Can you crack the code to safer roads and traffic accidents in Spain‚Äôs region of Catalunya?

2024 marks the 3rd year of the Ocean Protocol Data Challenge Program initiative. ‚ÄòRoad to Safety: Traffic Accident Analysis‚Äô is the first data challenge in 2024. The challenge launches today Jan 11, 2024, with a deadline to participate ending Jan 30, 2024, 23:59:59 UTC. Access to the challenge description and submission guidelines can be found on the Desights platform.

‚ÄòRoad to Safety: Traffic Accident Analysis‚Äô is based on over 20,000 traffic accident specifications in Catalunya from 2010‚Äì2021. The dataset set includes 57 different recorded metrics that dominate each column header in the dataset. This is a unique opportunity for data people to dive into real-world data and uncover insights that could shape the future of road safety in this region.

Challenge Overview

Objective: This challenge aims to dive deep and discover trends that cause traffic accidents in Catalunya. In this, you will also develop predictive models for future traffic accidents in the region. To execute, participants will need to analyze trends and patterns in historical data to identify key drivers of emissions in each region, accident type, and cause. Then, these findings will apply to your final report.

Analyze traffic accident data to identify patterns and propose solutions.

Data Set: Access to the dataset of traffic accidents in Catalunya is available for download It is available to download from the Ocean Market, here via the Mumbai Test Network (Polygon Testnet).

Column headers are defined in English. Row-by-row details are composed of different integer and string data points. Some are recorded in English, Catalin, or numbered.

Each field in the dataset is defined here.

Prizes: For 2024, we‚Äôve increased the prize pool to $6,500 USDC (payable in OCEAN) per challenge. This is distributed among the top 10 finishers, ensuring more participants can win. The prize breakdown is as follows: 1st place will receive $2,000, 2nd place $1,500, 3rd place $1,000, 4th and 5th places will get $500 each, and 6th through 10th places will each be awarded $200.

Additionally, in 2024 points towards the 2024 Data Challenge Championship Leaderboard will now be awarded to the top 10 finishers in each event, with 100 championship points up for grabs. The distribution will be 25 points for 1st place, 20 for 2nd, 18 for 3rd, 12 for 4th, 10 for 5th, and then 5, 4, 3, 2, and 1 point respectively from 6th to 10th place.

How to Participate

Sign Up to Desights: Create a profile in web3 style on Desights to join the data challenge and all future data challenges.

Timeline: The challenge runs from January 11, 2024, to January 30, 2024.

Submission Guidelines: Please follow the ‚ÄòEvaluation Criteria‚Äô and ‚ÄòReport Guidelines‚Äô sections of the challenge overview in Desights for proper submission guidelines.

For questions, comments, and community data science dialogue, reach out in our discord #data-science-hub channel: https://discord.gg/yFRPH9PCN4 for updates and new challenges. Stay tuned for updates and discussions on our blog page blog.oceanprotocol.com for progress throughout the year!

To see past, current, and future data challenges sponsored by Ocean, please visit https://oceanprotocol.com/earn/data-challenges.

About Ocean Protocol

Ocean was founded to level the playing field for AI and data. Ocean tools enable people to privately & securely publish, exchange, and consume data.

Follow Ocean on Twitter or Telegram to keep up to date. Chat directly with the Ocean community on Discord. Or, track Ocean progress now on GitHub.

‚ÄòRoad to Safety: Traffic Accident Analysis‚Äô Data Challenge Launch was originally published in Ocean Protocol on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

11:20 • 6 days ago

UbiSecure

Understanding ID Document Verification: A Guide to Secure Authentication

ID Document Verification was introduced to solve many of the issues that raise from services that require higher levels of authentication. Certain... The post Understanding ID Document Verification: A Guide to Secure Authentication appeared first on Ubisecure Digital Identity Management.

ID Document Verification was introduced to solve many of the issues that raise from services that require higher levels of authentication. Certain services require more reliable authentication methods, which offers higher assurance of the user‚Äôs identity. However, this can cause issues, especially for users of different nationalities. Lower-level authentication methods can often be used by all users regardless of their country of origin, whereas in the case of higher-level methods, it is not always the case. However, with the use of ID Document Verification it becomes easier for all users to prove their identity. In this blog, I will explore the basics surrounding ID Document Verification and some of the main features that support these solutions.

What is ID Document Verification?

The basic concept is that ‚Äì instead of using a  user ID and password to sign into an eService, I identify myself by scanning my identity document and taking a selfie or a video clip to prove who I am. I can scan the document by taking a picture of it according to instructions given by the service provider. The service uses different highly sophisticated AI (Artificial Intelligence) driven technologies to verify that the person in the picture or a video matches the one shown in the document.

There are several ID Document Verification service providers in the markets and as you can imagine there are some differences in the principles of how these services function. You might be interested to know how many different countries are supported by the solution, which ID documents are accepted, whether is there a need to install an app, is ID Document chip scanning supported, where is the ID document information stored, what type of fraud detection systems the solution uses and what is the price per authentication transaction, especially during the initial registration.

The most common ID documents accepted by these services are driver‚Äôs licenses, national ID cards and passports but depending on the country I am from there can be over ten different documents including residence permits and work permits among others that I can use to prove my identity. Depending on the service provider I can scan the identity documents using a web browser-based or app-based user interface. The result is the same, after the initial ID document scanning procedure I get access to the eService. But what happens when I want to access the same eService again?

The benefit of a browser-based version is that I don‚Äôt have to install a new app on my smart device. Generally, it can be a good solution for a one-time authentication. However, if the goal is to reuse my identity again without re-registration, then my ID document information must be sent to the service provider‚Äôs servers. Even though the information is stored in an encrypted format, many users do not necessarily like the idea that non-governmental 3rd party operator stores this kind of information in their servers.

The benefit of an app-based solution is that it provides me with the possibility to store the scanned identity document information in an encrypted format on my smart device. I have the option to remove this information at any point I want. However, many eService providers do not want to ask their customers to install additional apps on their smart devices.

How reliable is the ID Document Verification?

Can ID Document Verification methods be considered strong authentication methods? Often, strong authentication methods utilise at least two factors from the list of something the user knows (e.g. password, pin code, answer to a security question), something the user has (e.g. security token, digital certificate, an ID card, a  phone with a built-in hardware token, software token), and something the user is (e.g. typically biometrics such as fingerprint, iris scan, vein scan etc.).

ID Document Verification uses a variety of AI-driven fraud detection mechanisms, such as face matching to confirm that the person who took the selfie or a video is the same as on the document. Texture analysis makes sure that the pictures or videos are genuine and not copies. In addition, features such as audio processing, face tracking and mouth tracking ‚Äì where they have to say some specific words, turn my head, blink my eyes etc. ‚Äì can be utilised to further verify that we have the right person trying to access the service. And if the algorithm is still not sure if it is the right person, some solutions provide an option to ask a trained employee to verify the user and make the final decision. From this perspective, we can say that ID Document Verification Authentication methods can provide strong authentication.

However, as an example, in Finland the official strong authentication methods include BankID, national ID cards (requires a card reader) and Mobile PKI (Mobiilivarmenne in Finnish). These methods have gone through a complex certification process to prove the maturity of the solution. This is indicated by using a Level of Assurance (LoA) levels. LoA levels use the international 4-step scale and the EU 3-step scale in parallel in the following way:

International scale EU scale Notes LoA 1 Not used (EU uses 3-step scale) LoA 2 eIDAS Low LoA 3 eIDAS Substantial BankID, Mobile PKI LoA 4 eIDAS High National Identity Card

eIDAS = Electronic Identification, Authentication and Trust Services

Since ID Document Verification method vendors are private companies, they do not have such LoA certifications. From a security point of view, it is important to make sure that the vendor follows the latest developments in the standards and technology used to identify fraudulent documents.

Also, it is good to notice that in some European countries, it is possible to open a bank account online using ID Document Verification authentication, indicating that these banks trust their selected vendor‚Äôs solution ‚Äì which is a noteworthy seal of approval.

One way to improve the reliability of the scanning procedure is to scan the microchip in the ID Document. The chips inside of passports and national ID cards include user-specific certificates that are very difficult to forge, thus they can be used to increase the reliability of the document verification procedure. To do this, I have to make sure I have an NFC (Near-Field Communication) chip in my smart device. In addition, some solutions can run backend queries to external databases to validate documents‚Äô ID attributes and execute fraud evaluation against fraud databases.

Which services can use Identity Document Verification?

While ID Document Verification authentication methods have often been used in banking services, there are also many other services where they are very useful. This is especially useful where the eService requires a higher assurance of identity verification but the users cannot use the official strong authentication methods of the given country.

One good example of this is the universities. Very often these educational institutes have foreign students and teachers who need to authenticate themselves to access the university eServices to attend online lectures, examinations etc. Username and password methods are just not strong enough in these cases, but reliable online authentication methods are not available. This type of issue can be solved with ID Document Verification Authentication. Notice that the new European Digital Identity (EUDI), which is a part of the eIDAS regulation will allow EU-level cross-border strong authentication services. It will solve this issue for people who have EU-level digital identities. Read more about it here: https://www.ubisecure.com/standards/introducing-european-digital-identity-eudi/

In addition, several other eServices can use ID Document Verification for more convenient, passwordless authentication. Instead of writing my username and password I can just take a selfie (biometric facial recognition) or scan a QR code to access the service. Also, if the service has a password, I could reset it by taking a selfie.

Integrating an ID Document Verification Authentication service with a CIAM (Customer Identity and Access Management) solution such as Ubisecure‚Äôs Identity Platform makes the onboarding of new users frictionless. This type of solution can utilise the registration form autofill feature during the initial phase of the procedure. Many of the required attributes can be scanned directly from the ID document, thus users do not have to type them in manually.

The integration procedure can be established using the tools provided by the CIAM system. If the ID Document Verification Authentication service supports standard authentication protocols, such as SAML or OIDC, then it is a very straightforward procedure. If the service uses proprietary APIs, then a separate adapter needs to be created to establish communication between the CIAM and the service. This type of solution allows you to easily take the ID Document Verification Authentication service to use for all of your eServices with just a few mouse clicks.

Pros and cons of ID Document Verification

Below, I have listed some positives and negatives of the ID Document Verification Authentication services. It is good to remember that the solutions vary between different vendors. So, depending on your needs you can choose a vendor that fulfils your requirements.

Positives Negatives + International authentication method, not limited to one national ID ‚Äì Chip scanning requires a phone with NFC functionality + Passwordless authentication utilising:

+ QR-codes

+ Selfies

+ Videos

 

‚Äì Initial registration can sometimes be cumbersome + Difficult to forge (especially the methods based on chip scanning)

 

‚Äì Not all countries have centralised registries for attribute verification

 

+ Possibility to confirm scanned information from external registries

 

‚Äì Cannot cover 100% of customers. Some manual customer service processes still required for certain users

‚Äì The service can cover a maximum of just over 200 countries at best (depending on the service  provider)

‚Äì Not all users have the smart devices required available

‚Äì Not everyone has the documents required

‚Äì Not everyone has the know-how to complete the registration process

 

+ The possibility of doing a password reset using a recheck of a selfie or a video

 

‚Äì Initial authentication can be a bit expensive (for the eService provider)

 

+ Frictionless onboarding of new customers with registration form auto-filling when combined with CIAM

 

‚Äì Some solutions require the user‚Äôs ID Document information to be stored in an external DBs

 

+ Good for services that are subject to stringent KYC (Know Your Customer) and AML (Anti Money Laundering) requirements. ‚Äì There can be differing levels of accuracy different skin tones, genders and ages, enquire with your vendor about bias mitigation. Listen to Evaluating face recognition biometrics with Mei Ngan, NIST to find out more.

As we have seen, the official strong authentication methods are usually national-level solutions. Even with the EUDI service, we can offer only EU-level solutions for the problem. The ID Document Verification Authentication services can offer an option for strong authentication for global users. In addition, it can simplify the onboarding processes and provide passwordless sign-in to eServices. Its AI-powered biometric identification engines for facial recognition and anti-spoofing technologies make it a safe option for a variety of eServices.

Contact us to discuss ID Document Verification Authentication and how this could help your organisation.

The post Understanding ID Document Verification: A Guide to Secure Authentication appeared first on Ubisecure Digital Identity Management.

09:00 • 6 days ago

Top 5 DevCareer Hackathon Winners!

Round of applause for the top 5 DevCareer Hackathon winners! üëè

DevCareer ü§ù Web5 Hackathon‚Äã

It's winner announcement time! We're thrilled to have been a part of DevCareer's first-ever hackathon. DevCareer's mission is to cultivate new talent and make a difference in Africa through tech, and having that talent play around with our Web5.js sdk was an invaluable experience. The level of creativity resulted in us having not 3 but 5 winning projects! üöÄ

Hackathon Winners‚Äã ü•á P2Doc Heathcare‚Äã

P2Doc Heathcare was developed by team Game Changers. It's a decentralized healthcare data system that gives the power back to the patients. Allowing patients to disclose only the necessary parts of their medical history.

Try It Out:

Working Project GitHub Repo ü•à EazyJobs‚Äã

EazyJobs was developed by team Jobsters. It's a decentralized job search platform, where users own and control their job profile data.

Try It Out:

GitHub Repo Documentation ü•â yDID‚Äã

yDID was developed by team yDID. It's an application focused on truly managing digital identity. It allows users to consolidate their identity, including usernames, IDs, certifications and gaming rewards, into a single instance.

Try It Out:

GitHub Repo üèÖ Decentralized VR Museum‚Äã

Decentralized VR Museum was created by team Digital Dream Crafters. It's an immersive virtual reality experience that allows users secure access to art work.

Try It Out:

Video Demo GitHub Repo Documentation üèÖ Auth5‚Äã

Auth5 was developed by team MAVIGO. It's a authentication system that ensures personal data is stored on the users Decentralized Web Nodes. Allowing the user to control who can access their data.

Anders Ask√•sen from Okta and Martin Kuppinger discuss the impact on critical infrastructure organizations and the implications for identity management, particularly in authentication. Learn more about the key considerations, reporting challenges, liability aspects, and the role of identity in

Anders Ask√•sen from Okta and Martin Kuppinger discuss the impact on critical infrastructure organizations and the implications for identity management, particularly in authentication. Learn more about the key considerations, reporting challenges, liability aspects, and the role of identity in meeting NIS2 requirements.

SC Media - Identity and Access

Outlogic barred from peddling sensitive location data

Outlogic, the data broker previously known as X-Mode Social, has been prohibited by the Federal Trade Commission from engaging in the sale of Americans' geolocation data following the exposure of religious affiliations, medical visits, and more sensitive individual information from the raw data it sold to organizations across numerous industries, BleepingComputer reports.

Outlogic, the data broker previously known as X-Mode Social, has been prohibited by the Federal Trade Commission from engaging in the sale of Americans' geolocation data following the exposure of religious affiliations, medical visits, and more sensitive individual information from the raw data it sold to organizations across numerous industries, BleepingComputer reports.

Indicio

Associate Software Engineer (Remote)

Work with the Director of Sales to support him in day-to-day responsibilities including... The post Associate Software Engineer (Remote) appeared first on Indicio.
Associate Software Engineer (Remote)

Job Description

Come and make the world a better place by developing decentralized identity software and technologies! We want you to assist us in designing, writing, and testing code that will become a part of the products and solutions we deliver to customers. Increase privacy and control for users and lower risks and costs for organizations using cutting edge techniques for verifying data and establishing trusted digital relationships.

As an Associate position, this role is part-time (maximum 30 hours a week) and does not offer benefits, but the goal of our associate program is to help you grow into a full-time role. You‚Äôll report to the Sr. Enterprise Team Manager and work in partnership with your teammates and other functional teams to develop server-based applications. You‚Äôll have opportunities for mentorship, community outreach, publication and personal branding, and career and personal development. There are bi-weekly sprints, daily standups, peer programming sessions, and weekly game sessions. At Indicio, there are numerous opportunities to make an impact!

Indicio is a fully remote company and does not have an office. Our team is spread out across US and European time zones, and our clients are located all around the world. As you‚Äôll work remotely, you must be self-motivated, a demonstrated team-player, and have outstanding communication skills.

We do not conduct live coding interviews, but we do like to talk about your favorite projects and may ask for code samples if you are shortlisted.

Responsibilities

Be a part of the team process to design and scope features Work with other team members to schedule work and coordinate code delivery Write (and learn to write) high quality software Review and test code and workflows Document and demo the features you have created

Requirements

Experience writing code in JavaScript Working knowledge of Node.js, Express.js, and React.js Experience or desire in working remotely in a startup environment Working with urgency without direct supervision, taking initiative, and asking lots of questions Strong team working skills including empathy, always assuming the best intent, kindness, collaboration, and a desire to create impact Proficiency with the following tools is preferred, but familiarity with similar tools is just fine: Google Suite, JIRA, Git, GitHub, and Slack Must live in and be legally able to work in the US; we cannot sponsor work visas at this time

We highly encourage candidates of all backgrounds to apply to work with us ‚Äì we recruit based on more than just  official qualifications, including experience and curiosity. As a Public Benefit Corporation, a women-owned business, and WSOB certified, Indicio is committed to advancing decentralized identity as a public good that enables all people to control their online identities and share their data by consent. We aim to create a welcoming environment for our employees, clients, and partners and ensure a diverse, inclusive, and equitable environment.

Indicio Leadership Principles

 

Trust & Transparency

We trust each other to do what‚Äôs right and we trust the decisions being made at all levels of the company. We are transparent and share company information with teams regularly. Respect & Empowerment We are each empowered to make decisions and we respect those made by others. When compromises need to be made, we consider all opinions and do so with kindness. We believe in the ability of all our teammates to get their work done how, when, and where they feel most productive. We treat each other and our customers with the utmost respect.

 

Learning & Mentorship

We spend time and resources for the personal growth and education of all team members, our customers, and the decentralized identity community. Through continuous learning, mentorship, and feedback, we all improve together. Celebrate We are a joyful and happy company. We love where we work and celebrate our accomplishments! We are tenacious and positive in our work together and with customers‚Äìeven during challenging times. We celebrate our differences and take the time to get to know each other and all the aspects that make us special. Impact Every teammate is a leader, directly influences the success of Indicio, and understands the importance of this technology for humanity. We recognize we have power and responsibility as we develop this new technology. We can‚Äôt anticipate all its uses but we seek to reduce unintended consequences.

 

Inclusion

We are agents of change, working together to ensure both Indicio and our industry are safe places to work where every person belongs. As a Public Benefit Corporation, we serve worldwide communities in positive and inclusive ways.

The post Associate Software Engineer (Remote) appeared first on Indicio.

19:05 • 7 days ago

Senior Sales Manager (Remote)

The post Senior Sales Manager (Remote) appeared first on Indicio.
Senior Sales Manager

Job Description

Come and make the world a better place by helping to manage the business side of our ground-breaking work in developing decentralized digital identity solutions.  As a Public Benefit Corporation, a women-owned business, and WSOB certified, Indicio is committed to advancing decentralized identity as a public good that enables all people to control their online identities and share their data by consent.

This is a full-time, fully remote role with healthcare benefits, matching 401k, unlimited time off, and the opportunity for equity rewards.

You‚Äôll report to the VP of Business Development and work directly with them and the CEO in driving inbound and outbound sales, closing deals, and preparing SOWs. You will partner with the VP of Product, Director of Customer Success, and Technical leads in kicking off new client engagements.

We have opportunities for mentorship, community outreach, and career development. Indicio does not have an office and our team is spread out across US and European time zones, our clients are globally located, and some travel may be necessary. As you‚Äôll work remotely, you must be self-motivated, a demonstrated team-player, have outstanding analytic and communication skills,  and be able to demonstrate professional speaking and writing experience.

Responsibilities

Close enterprise level deals! Drive lead sourcing and qualification, follow ups to inbound leads,  and RFP applications Preparing, in coordination with Accounting, Operations, and Technical teams, Statements of Work (SOWs) Tracking all sales activity in Hubspot and Netsuite Provide feedback to the Marketing team on sales materials, decks, RFPs, and other items to drive successful customer meetings Tracking and presentation of Sales and Business Development KPIs to the leadership team

Requirements

Experience in sales and business development at an enterprise level in the technology industry Experience working in a start-up, we have a scrapy and fast paced environment Experience working remotely and demonstrating urgency without direct supervision Strong team working skills including empathy, always assuming the best intent, kindness, and desire to create impact Proficiency with the following tools is preferred, but familiarity with similar tools is acceptable: Google Suite, Hubspot, NetSuite, ClickUp, JIRA, and Slack Proficiency in data analysis and data visualization is not required but a benefit Must live in and be legally able to work in the US; we cannot sponsor work visas at this time

We highly encourage candidates of all backgrounds to apply to work with us ‚Äì we do not recruit based only on official qualifications but also on experience and curiosity. We always aim to ensure a diverse, inclusive, and equitable environment at Indicio.

Indicio Leadership Principles

 

Trust & Transparency

We trust each other to do what‚Äôs right and we trust the decisions being made at all levels of the company. We are transparent and share company information with teams regularly. Respect & Empowerment We are each empowered to make decisions and we respect those made by others. When compromises need to be made, we consider all opinions and do so with kindness. We believe in the ability of all our teammates to get their work done how, when, and where they feel most productive. We treat each other and our customers with the utmost respect.

 

Learning & Mentorship

We spend time and resources for the personal growth and education of all team members, our customers, and the decentralized identity community. Through continuous learning, mentorship, and feedback, we all improve together. Celebrate We are a joyful and happy company. We love where we work and celebrate our accomplishments! We are tenacious and positive in our work together and with customers‚Äìeven during challenging times. We celebrate our differences and take the time to get to know each other and all the aspects that make us special. Impact Every teammate is a leader, directly influences the success of Indicio, and understands the importance of this technology for humanity. We recognize we have power and responsibility as we develop this new technology. We can‚Äôt anticipate all its uses but we seek to reduce unintended consequences.

 

Inclusion

We are agents of change, working together to ensure both Indicio and our industry are safe places to work where every person belongs. As a Public Benefit Corporation, we serve worldwide communities in positive and inclusive ways.

The post Senior Sales Manager (Remote) appeared first on Indicio.

19:03 • 7 days ago

Ontology
